Medicine Name Enter Medicine Medicine Days Treatment deadline Continuous use Reminder NEW MEDICINE Every day No Medicine Added Error while loading medicineAlarms Medicine Added Scuccessfully It's Time to take your medicine IGNORED TAKEN ALL Filter All Medicines Medicines Ignored Medicine Taken No History Found You have not taken any medicine Well Done Monthly Report BMI Blood Group Save Age (in years) Height (in cms) Weight (in kgs) About Facilities Book Appointment MedBot Emergency Contact No. 1).If the patient is conscious in distress, move him into a comfortable position
 2)Loosen any tight clothing 
 3)Regularly check and make a note of consciousness, breathing, and pulse.
Suddenly feels faint or dizzy
 Severe chest pain (persistent and vice-like, spreading up to the jaw and down one or both arms) that does not subside when the patient rests
 Discomfort high in the abdomen (may feel like severe indigestion)
 Breathlessness (patient may be gasping for air)
 Fear (feels an impending sense of doom)
 Pale, gray, clammy, or sweaty skin
 Rapid, weak, and irregular pulse
 Collapses, often without warning
 Possible loss of consciousness
Move the person beyond striking distance of the snake.
 Have the person lie down with wound below the heart.
 Keep the person calm and at rest, remaining as still as possible to keep venom from spreading.
 Cover the wound with loose, sterile bandage.
 Remove any jewelry from the area that was bitten.
 Remove shoes if the leg or foot was bitten.
Stop any bleeding.
Immobilize the injured area.
Apply ice packs to limit swelling and help relieve pain.
Treat for shock.
The person is unresponsive, isn't breathing or isn't moving.
 There is heavy bleeding.
 Even gentle pressure or movement causes pain.
 The limb or joint appears deformed.
 The bone has pierced the skin.
 You suspect a bone is broken in the neck, head or back.
Cool the burn.
 Remove rings or other tight items.
 Apply lotion.
 Bandage the burn.
 Take a pain reliever. Quick Access EXAMPLE Add widget Health Schemes
